intro: Temnadenia tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It is native to parts of southern Africa and is characterized by its dense, woolly white pubescence covering its stems and leaves. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves that are often clustered in whorls along the stems. It produces tiny, pinkish-white flowers followed by small, red berries that are a food source for birds. Due to its parasitic nature, it can affect the health of its host trees if not managed properly.
